comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Although it doesn't help date the photograph, the large building in the background with a mock-Tudor front is Allambie House.  

It does not exist today.

comment.author: 48569388@N00
comment._content: Looks like the first and third cars from the left are Ford Model As - though Australian Ford plants tended to deviate from regular bodies, but these seem similar. here's a link to a 1930 Australian Ford Model A, looks spot on. That puts the picture to at least post 1927, probably later. Fashion-wise, it's hard to tell, but I'd hazard a guess that it's in the 30s, though with those hats on the women in the middle, maybe a smidge later? I'm not sure how much Australian fashion differed from English & American, so I hesitate to date. Hope this helps! (as to the above, knowing the name of that house *does* date the photograph! we can find out when Allambie was torn down and date from there...)

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Global Australians , and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: There is a great comment about the cars in this image over on the blog post . To quote the start: "The cars are from late 1920s to 1939, and vehicles from all those years were common enough on the roads until the 1960s, so maybe the fashion experts can narrow it for you. Left to right: Car 1 – the straight up and down windscreen pillar and rear sedan tub indicates most likely to be 1926-1928 US make of smaller sedan –Chev, Essex, Buick, Oldsmobile maybe but without more detail of the radiator and headlamps could be an example of at least 20 different models in those years...."

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...

comment._content: Over on your blog, there is some really great analytical information being contributed.  Good to know there is a vintage car expert looking in.

comment.author: 44782571@N04
comment._content:
The first car looks very much like a 4-door 1929 Nash car. I have a photo of my grandfather's Nash car. You can easily find photos of Nash cars on the web.

I'm not sure if the third car is also a Nash car. It's proportions look a little different.

As far as the women's fashions go; the skirt length appears to be to the knee. During WW11 skirt hemlines were to the knee (through necessity to economise with fabric). After the war hemlines dropped to below the knee again, until the 1960s when hemlines were well above the knee; the mini skirt. 

The skirt hemline in the 1930s was just below mid-calf. In the late 1940s it was just above mid-calf. The 1950s were generally just below the knee.

To have so many cars of the 1930s vintage in the photo doesn't make it look like the 1950s or 60s. 

Cars in the 1940s were getting a rounded look as with the fourth vehicle. My guess is that during WW11 there would have been a lot of older cars still in use.

So I would date this photo in the 1940s during wartime.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks to everyone for all your help dating this photo - we have added a c.1930s date.
